awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Research Experience for Undergraduates in Nanoscale Science and Engineering
awd_abstract_narration:
Nanotechnology is one of the fastest-growing research areas and is widely recognized as having the potential to revolutionize fields as wide-ranging as energy, medicine, environmental science, and biotechnology. It is also an area that integrates disciplines, generating a highly creative environment that breaks down traditional academic silos. At Northwestern University, nanotechnology is recognized as one of the pillars of excellence, due in large part to the International Institute for Nanotechnology (IIN). This Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site for Nanoscale Science and Engineering at Northwestern University, hosted by the IIN, will provide diverse cohorts of undergraduates with meaningful, goal-oriented, laboratory research experiences for a 9-week period over the summer. The foundation of scientific and technological progress is an educated and motivated scientific workforce. Research is a valuable experience in critical thinking and skill development for undergraduates, and summer research experiences - that are not fragmented by classwork and extracurricular obligations - are especially valuable for exposing undergraduates to realistic day-to-day operations of a research lab, and for allowing them to engage deeply in a single challenging research project.

During the summer IIN will host a unique program in an intellectually stimulating environment that provides research opportunities in Chemistry, Biology, Medicine, Physics, and several Engineering disciplines, all connected through their focus on nanoscience and nanotechnology. This REU program strongly emphasizes the recruitment of undergraduates from institutions where academic-year research opportunities and/or resources to conduct scientific research are scarce, in order to increase the representation of all ethnicities, genders, and socioeconomic groups in the STEM workforce. Each student will be mentored by a faculty member and a graduate student team within a framework that moves from guided supervision to independent work as abilities allow. The students will problem solve and contribute to the development of new tools, materials, and methods while exploring nanoscale and atomic-scale systems, phenomena, and devices. The cohort will be strengthened by weekly meetings/seminars, field trips, social activities, and shared on-campus housing. The program will include an interactive public speaking workshop, one-on-one technical writing sessions, and access and training on state-of-the-art instrumentation. Participants will present their findings at a Closing Symposium and in a written technical report.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report

Undergraduate Research in Nanotechnology ? Educating Tomorrow?s Scientists Today

Emily A. Weiss, Northwestern University

Outcome: The NU REU Site advanced the knowledge and research skills of undergraduate researchers.  The significance of the program is clear when examining the program's exit survey results.  A majority of students reported that the program had engaged them in real world scientific research, improved their problem-solving skills, and enhanced their ability to write scientific reports or papers.

Impact/Benefit:  Overall, the NU REU Site encouraged students to consider careers in science and engineering by emphasizing the interdisciplinary nature of nanoscale science, chemistry, materials science, and medicine, and provided access to exceptional research opportunities in Nanoscale Science and Engineering.

Explanation:  There is a critical need for the creation of a strong workforce of world-class scientists, engineers, and educators with competencies in interdisciplinary nanoscience and nanotechnology research.  The REU Site in Nanoscale Science and Engineering at Northwestern University (NU) program uniquely equipped 29 undergraduate students with hands-on, interdisciplinary research opportunities to broaden participation in nanoscale research.  The NU REU Site supported undergraduate students, from colleges and universities around the country, in a diverse array of meaningful nanoscale science and engineering research projects.

NU REU participants were a demographically diverse group.  45% of participants were female, and 38% were underrepresented racial and ethnic minorities.  A broad range of educational institutions were also represented, with 24% of the participating students from smaller schools with limited research opportunities.

Due to the pandemic, there was a two year pause in the program.  In 2019 and 2022, during a nine-week summer program, each participant was assigned a research project under the careful guidance of a faculty advisor, and graduate student or postdoctoral associate mentor, who was actively involved in the daily supervision and mentoring of their assigned undergraduates. The program included a full-day public speaking workshop, an individualized writing workshop to build communication skills, an ethics seminar, and a field trip to Argonne National Laboratories. At the close of the program, participants presented final project results at a formal Closing Symposium and submitted a final research paper.

Students describe the NU REU Site as a life-changing experience.  One student's exit survey stated: "I feel like I got a good idea of what graduate school is like and now I know I definitely want to pursue that, and I like the research and would like to do something similar in the future!" Another student said: "My research has prepared me for graduate school. I don't get the kind of exposure to research at my home institution that I got at NU, so I wanted this experience to prepare me in some ways for the type of research I will be doing in the future." Finally, another undergraduate commented: "I think working around actual graduate students and seeing the work that they do made graduate school and attaining a PhD a bit more real and achievable. So, it definitely did give me the courage to keep trying."

NSF Award Number:   EEC 1757618

Award Title:                 REU Site in Nanoscale Science and Engineering

PI:                                 Emily Weiss, e-weiss@northwestern.edu

Institution Name:        Northwestern University
